awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Neutron-Induced Backgrounds on 134.136Xe for Large-Scale Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decay Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
The process of radioactive decay of nuclei has been known for some time.  The usual process of decay is known as beta-decay, where the nucleus emits an energetic electron, thereby turning a neutron into a proton and, at the same time, emitting a ghostly particle called an antineutrino.  This process has been measured and theoretically modeled with excellent agreement.  In rare cases, some nuclei can emit two electrons simultaneously, along with two antineutrinos, in a process called double beta-decay.  This process is difficult to measure, because it is so rare, and difficult to calculate because of uncertainties in the nuclear structure.  The goal of this research is to reduce the uncertainties in nuclear structure by measuring nuclear reactions relevant to the double beta-decay process. This will help in the understanding of experiments on neutrinoless double beta-decay, a proposed beta-decay process in which no neutrinos are observed.  The search for this elusive decay mode has been identified by the Nuclear Science Advisory Committee as one of the most important questions facing nuclear science, since those experiments would provide critical information on the fundamental properties of neutrinos and antineutrinos.

One potential background contribution to experiments of double beta-decay comes from neutrons hitting either the source material or nearby shielding materials.  These neutrons can create more neutrons, or can create gamma rays to mimic the desired signal.  Several current experiments are studying the neutrinoless double-beta decay of isotope xenon-136. A similar isotope, xenon-134, is also present as an impurity, which was recently discovered to emit a potential background event when hit with neutrons. The research conducted with this award will investigate this recently-discovered background using a highly-enriched gaseous xenon target. The gaseous xenon sample will be irradiated with neutrons at the Triangle Universities Nuclear Laboratory, and then will be counted using a shielded high-purity germanium detector in the Low Background Counting Facility. The research performed under this award will extend our knowledge of potential double beta decay backgrounds in xenon, which will assist in planning the future ton-scale neutrinoless double beta decay experiments. Since observation of neutrinoless double beta decay is a major component of the nuclear science long-range plan, gaining information regarding backgrounds is essential.

por.por_cntn:
The major concern in neutrinoless double-beta decay experiments is background. Due to the extremely long half life of these decays, the background count in the region of interest must be less than 1 count in the region of interest per ton of material per year. As we scale up to the ton-scale level, this restriction becomes even more severe.

One such background comes from neutrons produced either by cosmic rays or from (α, n) reactions in nearby shielding materials. These neutrons can create gamma rays via inelastic scattering (n,n'γ) or neutron radiative capture, or they can create more neutrons via the (n, 2n) reaction.

Over the original three-year period of this project, we proposed to measure cross sections of the following reactions:  134Xe(n, n’γ)134Xe at incident neutron energies ranging from 4 to 10 MeV, 134Xe(n, 2n)133Xe from 10-13 MeV,  134Xe(n, γ)135Xe from 0.5 to 7.5 MeV, and 136Xe(n,n’γ)136Xe from 4 to 10 MeV.  Better knowledge of these cross sections will allow more accurate predictictions of the neutron-induced internal background in neutrinoless double-beta (0νββ) decay searches.  We completed these measurements and are in the process of analyzing and completing cross-section calculations for these reactions.  In addition, we have also taken neutron inelastic scattering data on 76Ge, Te, and Mo, expanding the scope of the original proposal significantly.

The students who work on this project learn many skills that are valuable to physicists.  They calibrate data from germanium detectors, learn how to calculate efficiencies, learn to use the National Nuclear Data Center, and learn how to disseminate their results.  In the act of facilitating these experiences, a set of exercises has been developed to guide students through a dataset before they ever touch their actual data.   

Beyond the impact on science and technology, this project significantly affects the experiences of physics undergraduates.  Many of the students supported by this grant have grown up in Tennessee and may have never left the state, or at least the southeast.  This project has enabled them to travel to Duke University and experience what it is like to work at a particle accelerator.  It has also funded their travel to conferences, where they can learn how to present their research as well as make contacts for graduate school experiences.
